content: P.L. 106-554, signed in December 2000, enacted the Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and General Government Appropriations, 2001. It provided funding for various accounts, including the General Services Administration for transition administration and the Executive Residence for White House family transfers. P.L. 106-346 (H.R. 4475) partially funded select accounts from the primary funding measure. Various measures were considered before the enactment of P.L. 106-554 for FY2001 appropriations. These bills provide funding for accounts within the Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and General Government for FY2001. Treasury appropriations cover various agencies including the Secret Service, Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, and Federal Law Enforcement Training Center. Funding also supports the U.S. Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and independent agencies like the Federal Election Commission and National Archives. The Treasury and General Government appropriation funds independent agencies like the Federal Election Commission, General Services Administration, National Archives, Office of Personnel Management, Office of Special Counsel, and the United States Tax Court. The appropriation includes general titles with governmentwide restrictions and authorities for defined actions, such as prohibiting the use of funds for non-U.S. citizens' employment and authorizing travel expenses for immediate family members of federal employees serving overseas in case of death or life-threatening illness. New provisions in titles V and VI are also presented. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001 includes a .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations funds affecting all accounts in the Treasury and General Government appropriations. The Office of Management and Budget is required to report on the implementation of the rescission when the FY2002 budget is submitted. The rescission applies to all net positive discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations, including advance appropriations for FY 2001 provided in FY 2000 or earlier years. Discretionary emergency appropriations are also subject to the rescission, with a requirement for the reduction to be applied equally to each program, project, and activity. The Act mandates a 0.22% reduction in discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations, affecting all accounts. Agencies must allocate the reduction equally to each program, project, and activity without exception. The rescission cannot be applied to mandatory funds or transfers. Agencies will receive their specific rescission amounts from OMB and must make reductions only from discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations.
